Margitfalvi Central Research Institute for Chemistry of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, 1025 Budapest, Pusztaszeri fit 59-67, Hungary Received 28 May 1996; revised 19 September 1996; accepted 19 September 1996 Abstract The condensation of allyl alcohol with ammonia was studied over phosphoric acid catalyst supported on controlled pore glass (CPG). The above catalyst was compared with silica supported phosphoric acid. The CPG supported catalyst showed higher selectivity and lower rate of deactivation than the corresponding silica supported one. The above difference can be attributed to both the boron content and the large pore size of the CPG support. Keywords: Allylamine; Allyl alcohol; Amination; Controlled pore glass (CPG); Phosphoric acid; Supported phosphoric acid 1. Introduction Allylamines, useful as pharmaceutical and agrochemical intermediates, are usually prepared by the ammonolysis of allyl halides [1]. It has been found that the reaction of allyl alcohol (AAL) with ammonia in the presence of acid phosphate catalysts provides allylamine with high selectivity [2-4]. The condensation of C3-C6 unsaturated alcohols with ammonia or CI-C4 alkylamines in the presence of rare earth phosphate catalysts (La2(HPO4)3, Nd2(HPO4)3, Ce2(HPO4)3) was studied by Wells and Eskinazi [3]. Di- and triallylamine (DAA and TAA) and [3-picoline was formed as by-products [3]. Daughenbaugh and Dixon [2] investigated the reaction of allyl alcohol and 2- methyl-allyl alcohol with C~-C5 primary or secondary amines in vapor or liquid phase in the presence of supported H3PO4, BPO4, FePO4, Fe3(PO4)2 and AIPO4 catalysts. Boron phosphate, probably, due to its low surface area had low activity in the condensation of allyl alcohol with ammonia [2]. Reacting allylalcohol with ammonia on silica supported phosphorous acid the increase of the temperature in the range of 195-320 resulted in an increase of the conversion of alcohol from 1.3 to 23.0% and a decrease of the selectivity of MAA from 100 to 81%. Carrol and co-workers [4] reacted allyl alcohol with ammonia over H3PO4/SiO2 and LaPO4 catalysts. The highest monoallylamine yield (16-18%) was obtained at 320 and LaPO4 appeared to be less active than silica supported phosphorous acid. At higher temperatures the side reactions were the acid catalyzed oligomer- ization of allylalcohol and the formation of 13-picoline. In this paper the catalytic activity of controlled pore glass (CPG) supported phosphorous acid in the selective preparation of monoallylamine via condensation of allyl alcohol with ammonia will be demonstrated. The increased selectivity and stability of the catalyst, due to the boron content and large pore size of CPG will also be discussed. 2. Experimental 2.1. Chemicals Silica supplied by Ventron (unit surface area (S) =285 m2 g-l, pore volume (Vp) 1.06 cm3 g-l, and pore diameter (dp) =10 nm) and controlled pore glass from Institute for Silicate Technologies (Budapest, Hungary) (S =8.9m2g-1, Vp 0.322cm3 g-l, dp =154nm) were used as support. Phosphoric acid (85% H3PO4, d = 1.684 g cm-3) from Reanal (Hungary) and allyl alcohol from Merck was used for the catalyst preparation and activity test, respectively. In catalytic runs pure ammonia and 75% hydrogen-25% nitrogen mixture was used. 2.2. Preparation of catalysts Phosphoric acid-containing solid catalysts were prepared by impregnating silica and CPG supports with an aqueous solution of HaPO4. The pretreatment of the catalysts was carried out in H2-Ne mixture at 300 for 2 h (flow rate: 300 cm3 min-1, heating rate: 3 min-1). S. G6bOl6s et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 152 (1997) 63-68 65 2.3. Characterization of catalysts Textural properties (pore size distribution, average pore size and pore volume in the range above 8 nm) were measured by mercury porosimetry using a computer controlled Carlo Erba 2000 porosimeter. Surface concentration of boron oxide in CPG was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a Kratos XSAM 800 spectrometer. XPS spectra of Ols, Cls, Si2p and Bls levels were recorded using Mg Kfa =1253.6 eV irradiation. 2.4. Activity test Catalytic activity tests were carded out in a stainless steel continuous-flow reactor (V =20 cm3, inner diameter =15 mm) in the vapor phase under pressure. Carrier gas (mixture of hydrogen and nitrogen) was introduced through a saturator filled with liquid phase ammonia at 0. Allyl alcohol was introduced by a high pressure pump. Reaction conditions were: catalyst: 10 g (particle size: 0.09-0.31 mm); PNH3 0.45 MPa; Ptota1:0.7 MPa, NH3/alcohol ----4; H2/NH3 =0.4; WHSV =1 g g-1 h-l, Treaction =260-360. 2.5. Analysis The analysis of the liquid reaction products was performed on a Carlo Erba GC 6000 chromatograph using FID and a glass column (3m x 3ram) filled with 60/80 mesh Chromosorb P NAW +5 wt% KOH +18 wt% Carbowax 20M packing material. Carrier gas: nitrogen. Temperature program: 80, 8 min, 10 min-1; 160, 4 min. 3. Results and discussion The textural properties of the fresh and used catalysts are given in Table 1. It is noteworthy, that the introduction of phosphoric acid into CPG resulted in a decrease of both the pore volume and surface area of the 5, 9 and 13 wt% P/CPG catalysts to 0.27, 0.19 and 0.13 cm3 g-1 and 7.5, 5.7 and 4.4 m2 g- 1, respectively. It is worth mentioning, that upon introducing phosphoric acid, the average pore size and the pore size distribution of CPG was only slightly altered. In the used SiO2 supported catalyst the pore volume and the surface area of the SiO2 support significantly decreased, whereas the average pore size of the support slightly increased probably due to "plugging" small pores by carbonaceous deposits formed in the reacion at 300. Conversion data, selectivities and the deactivation rate of the condensation of allyl alcohol with ammonia over silica and CPG supported phosphoric acid catalyst are summarized in Table 2. Data listed in Table 2 indicated that the 5% P/SiO2 catalyst was more active but less selective towards mono-allylamine and deacti- vated faster than the 5 % P/CPG catalyst. The main by-products of the condensation reaction were 13-picoline and diallylether. Over both catalysts upon increasing the reaction temperature from 280 to 320 the conversion of alcohol and the rate of deactivation significantly increased, whereas the selectivity to MAA decreased (compare experiments No. 1-No.3 and No.4-No.6). However, both the selectivity changes and the deactivation pattern is less pronounced over the CPG supported catalyst than over the silica supported one. Upon increasing the phosphorus content of CPG support from 5 to 9 and 13 wt% both the conversion of allylalcohol and the rate of deactivation increased and the selectivity to allylamine decreased (compare experiments No.4-No.6 and No.7- No.10). The increase of the reaction temperature to 350-370 resulted in the formation of large amount of by-products and led to fast deactivation (see experiments No.7-No.9). The increased acid content resulted in pronounced oligomerization and pore plugging responsible for the deactivation. This result shows that the deactivation is strongly related to side reactions. As known, controlled pore glass contains 3-4 wt% B203 [5]. Enrichment of boron oxide in the surface layer (3-6 nm in depth) of CPG was detected by XPS. The surface atomic ratio of B/Si was 0.09, whereas the atomic ratio of B/Si in the bulk was 0.05. Therefore, in the case of CPG supported phosphoric acid catalyst the high selectivity to allylamine can, probably, be explained by the formation of boron phosphate surface species during the pretreatment of the catalyst at 300 and its contribution to the overall catalytic performance. It is interesting to mention that in preliminary experiments silica and CPG supported boron phosphate catalysts appeared to be poorly active in the condensation of allyl alcohol with ammonia. This can probably be explained by the low dispersion of BPO4 on the supports. 4. Conclusion In conclusion, condensation of allyl alcohol with ammonia in the presence of controlled pore glass supported phosphoric acid provided 15-25% alcohol con- version and 74-84% selectivity to monoallylamine in the temperature range of 280-320. In the amination of allyl alcohol phosphoric acid on CPG is more active than on silica. This can, probably, be attributed to the formation of boron phosphate surface species during the high temperature pretreatment of the CPG supported catalyst. It is suggested that the formed boron phosphate surface species could be the sites involved in the formation of allylamine, while the presence of excess of phosphoric acid could be responsible for the undesired side reactions and catalyst deactivation. Due to the large pore size (d= 150 nm) of CPG the deactiva- tion of H3PO4/CPG catalyst by pore "plugging" was slower than that of H3PO4/ SiO2 catalyst.
